script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good morning! I'm Dr. Martinez. I understand you're here today because of some concerns about anxiety and depression. Can you tell me what's been going on?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't know... I just feel really anxious all the time and sad. Like nothing matters anymore.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: She's been having panic attacks at school and crying herself to sleep almost every night for the past two months.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I think she's just stressed about high school starting. This is normal teenage stuff, right? She doesn't need medication or therapy.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Tom, this is not normal! She missed twelve days of school last month because of the anxiety.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me ask a few more questions. Sarah, how long have you been feeling this way?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Maybe since the beginning of the school year? But it's gotten way worse lately.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Have you had any thoughts about hurting yourself or not wanting to be here anymore?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Sometimes I think about it... but I wouldn't actually do anything.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: See, she's fine! She's not going to hurt herself. We just need to toughen up a bit.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Tom! That's exactly the wrong thing to say right now!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I can see there are different perspectives here. Sarah, it sounds like you're really struggling. Can you tell me about your sleep and appetite?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I barely sleep. Maybe three or four hours a night. And I'm not really hungry anymore.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any family history of anxiety or depression that you know of?

script.speaker: mom
script.text: My sister has depression and takes medication for it. It runs in my family.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: That doesn't mean Sarah has to go down that path. We can handle this ourselves.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I understand your concerns about treatment, but given Sarah's symptoms - the panic attacks, sleep disturbance, appetite changes, and occasional thoughts of self-harm - this does meet criteria for clinical depression and anxiety.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't want to talk about this anymore. Can we just go home?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Sarah, I know this is hard to discuss, but getting help is really important for feeling better. We have several treatment options.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I said I don't want to talk about it!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, let's move on then. I'd like to discuss treatment recommendations with your parents.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: What do you recommend, doctor?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'd recommend starting with therapy - specifically cognitive behavioral therapy - and we should also consider a low-dose SSRI medication.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: Absolutely not. No medications. She's only fourteen years old.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: But if it helps her feel better, shouldn't we try it?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: The research shows that the combination of therapy and medication is most effective for moderate to severe depression in adolescents.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I don't care about research. I'm not putting my daughter on psychiatric drugs.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Maybe... maybe I could try just talking to someone first?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a great start, Sarah. We can begin with therapy and see how you respond. I'll give you some referrals for therapists who specialize in teen anxiety and depression.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Thank you, doctor. Should we schedule a follow-up?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, let's see you back in four weeks to see how therapy is going. And Sarah, if things get worse, especially those thoughts we talked about, please call me immediately.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay... I guess.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: We appreciate your time, doctor.
